Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 10:38PM - edited May 24, 2010 10:39PM by cwrightrn Wow--this is a hard one!  On the one hand, I like the idea of the kids having (in this case) men to go to for advice...to step in when Dad's not there....but on the other hand there's just something that is hard about it (emotionally that is.)  I love your "Linda's living database"--too funny! My kids are 15, 14, 12....the youngest is my only girl.  She and I have had discussions about how our lives are parallel in many ways: both of us had to grow up quick--in her case because mom is sick, in my case it was because my mom worked and I lived in an abusive home.  But I cooked, cleaned, watched after an infant sister--at age 12--and that was after having hip surgery at age 11 and being in a wheelchair for 6 months.  My mom was just never there and we didn't have the relationship that my daughter and I do.  Just recently I had a talk with my daughter about the fact that although my mom and I weren't close, that other women stepped into that role at different times in my life...my Aunts, older ladies at church, etc....and I assured her that it would be the same for her---that God would give her other women to lean on when needed.  I have talked to some women family members about it (names who I mentioned to my daughter) and they all assured me they would be there for her. Anyway, that's my two cents....
Posts.Title: counsel of dads Fitztwins Fitztwins

Posts.Content: May 19, 2010 08:32PM cwrightrn wrote: I went on a leave of absence from work 2/09 and had short term disability (from my job) to fill in the 180 day elimination period for long term disability.  Then I switched to long term disability through my job.  Both my oncologist and long term disability company encouraged me to apply for social security but I was under the delusion that I was going to get back to work so I waited and continued to collect long term disability.  When I did finally apply for social security disability, the process was done over the computer and then a phone interview and it went very well and quick approval process.  I DID GET retro money BUT IT HAD TO BE PAID BACK to the long term disability company.  so now I get social security money for me, for each of my three kids separately and I still get long term disability BUT the long term disability SUBTRACTS the social security amount.  I can continue to get the long term disability through my employer (even if I'm not employed) for up to 5 years....that will disappear upon my death.  And I agree with the earlier post, my social security money will be split between my 3 kids upon my death and when my oldest turns 18 it is then split between the 2 younger kids.  When my second oldest child turns 18 then a portion of the social security will go to my youngest til she turns 18.  I'm thankful that I have worked for 20 years and made enough money for the social security to be a substantial amount. Hope that helps....that was my experience

Posts.Title: pain with ixempra dfleaman Irina

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2010 05:48PM cwrightrn wrote: Hi there....just home from a camping trip to the lake.  Linda, I feel your pain honey!  Before we left for our trip the Dr called me after I requested she contact the pulmonologist.  Here's what their recommendations were for me-- !. pleurix tube, where they leave a tube in during the thoracentesis and you empty it out on your own at home.  My problem is that I have skin cancer on my chest and that is where the tube would come out so its not an option for me.  My Dr said they use it a lot in hospice but not with active people. 2. VATS procedure- where a cardiothoracic surgeon does a thorascopy, removes the fluid, puts in talc and a chest tube and you sit in the hospital waiting for the hole to seal.  This is very invasive and she said that with my history of fluid build up, I could be in the hospital quite awhile. Then she talked to me about switching chemo....bye bye xeloda and Ixempra and hello to gemzar and carboplat.  I asked her if it was possible the pleural effusion could be helped by new chemo and she said yes so I asked about just doing another thoracentesis which is the least invasive and hope the chemo works.  So I'm going to do a chest xray Monday and see how bad its gotten in 2 weeks and then do a thoracentesis later this week. I also finally consented to oxygen at home.  We took some camping (we have a 30 foot trailer so its luxury camping) and I used it at night.  My hubby thinks it helps my work of breathing but I find it drying and makes me cough more....who knows. Linda, I so understand the feeling of getting worse...and I HATE the breathing problems!  You can cry on my shoulder any time....I'm right there with you Blessings and hugs Carole
Posts.Title: Still short of breath after a thoracentesis cwrightrn cwrightrn

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 09:51AM cwrightrn wrote: Linda, please let me know what your options are....I'm rethinking the thoracentesis, especially if I know it is only going to fill back up. as to the chemo option, she wanted me to do a Parp for compassionate use but she said there are 2 arms to the Parp and both arms are coming out with the same results so they are having a hard time releasing the Parp because of the study results.....interesting.  That is why she is just doing gemzar/ carbo.  Doxil is a choice some ladies have had success with but my Dr said it is more for lobular cancers and I have IBC (IDC with skin mets).  She said I am about 1/2 way through my stage 4 options. Better run get my xray done Keep in touch Linda Blessings and hugs

Hope you are hanging in there Linda
Posts.Title: Still short of breath after a thoracentesis cwrightrn cwrightrn

Posts.Content: cwrightrn wrote: HI there ladies!  I had a CT of the abd/chest last week to see how I was doing on Ixempra and Xeloda and all cancer spots were stable or a bit better BUT it identified a pleural effusion.  I have had a cough since january with a hoarse voice and shortness of breath for the last few months.  We aren't sure how long I've had the effusion since my last scan/xray was 3months ago.  Anyway, they did the thoracentesis under ultrasound on Wednesday and got out 1 liter which I thought was a lot.  Immediately I started coughing coughing coughing and was wheezy.  I felt like there was fluid shifting around in my chest and figured out it felt like lymphedema.  anyway, we asked the radiologist to do a chest xray after the procedure and its not standard protocol.  he told me my symptoms were normal and it takes up to 2 hours for the lung to re-expand after the fluid is gone.  Well, its 2 days later and I'm still coughing (didn't expect that to go away) and I'm still short of breath--about the same as before, if not a bit more.  UGH!  I was expecting that to go away.  Anyone out there continue to have shortness of breath after a thoracentesis?  I've had family here all month so I haven't been in a hurry to call the Dr.  I go in on Monday for IV chemo and will address it then but just wondered if anyone out there had a similar experience. Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2010 10:14PM cwrightrn wrote: What a caring and loving daughter you are!  I'm so sorry to hear about your mom but without a lot of specifics there's no way for any of us here to know a time frame--heck, even the doctors don't know time frames...they are just guesses.  So we continue to pray and hope and live each day to the fullest.  One of my mottos is "don't let the worries of tomorrow rob you of the joy of today."  Enjoy your mom, spend time, talk to her, let her know how you're feeling and cherish your time. Your mom is one lucky lady to have you! Blessings and hugs Carole
Posts.Title: stage 3-4 breast cancer jesslpz242 MJLToday

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2010 04:49PM - edited Jul 31, 2010 04:51PM by cwrightrn Diane--our stories are similar except I was diagnosed at age 39.  My kids are 16,15,12.  I'm also triple negative and will be on chemo the rest of my life....but mine isn't working right now as I am developing the pleural effusions that keep coming back.  This last week I found out that the fluid they drained from the pleural effusion is malignant, they may need to switch chemo, I'm still short of breath, I ended up with blisters on my feet from xeloda and couldn't walk for 2 days, and my Dr recommended me for and adult version of the make a wish foundation and she has to sign off that I have less than a year to live.  We have never discussed prognosis....she is like your Dr....you are young and FIGHT FIGHT FIGHT.  But it was a lot in one week--yikes You are not alone my friend Blessings and hugs Carole   ps--sometimes you just need a break from the boards too so give yourself that break
Posts.Title: Need Encouragement.... angelsabove Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2010 06:43PM cwrightrn wrote: Stem cell transplants are no longer an approved treatment for breast cancer- it was proven to be no more effective than high dose chemo.  There are a few clinical trials out there--like at MD Anderson.  There are some ladies here that have gone through it....it is brutal....but so is chemo. Express your frustration and concern to your doctors and see what they recommend or where they would send you for a possible clinical trial. Hang in there....good luck on your journey

Posts.Content: cwrightrn wrote: I am 4 weeks post bilateral mastectomy and today I had my second post op visit. 2 drains were removed at the first visit, today one more was removed but the last remaining one on my lymph node dissection arm is still putting out about 100cc/day!  I have another appt in 3 weeks which will mean the drain will be in for 7 weeks!  The surgeon mentioned using an ace wrap as a compression dressing- loose at the top and tighter around the incision to try to get the skin to adhere to the muscle so the fluid finds somewhere else to go.  I asked about a sports bra and she said no because it is too constrictive under the arms.  Where can I find maybe a compression shirt (plus size, I wore size 16-18 and was a DDD pre-op) or something else that is easier than an ace wrap? And that might look nicer under clothes?  And how long do you wear it for?  She also mentioned using one of those rice bags that you can heat and put behind your neck....she said not to heat it but it would be the right weight to put on the incision when I am reclining. Let me know if any of you had to do this and how long you had your drains in for.....this is delaying my radiation and I am concerned because I have IBC my skin was still positive for cancer at surgery. Thanks for your thoughts.... Visit our blog: www.wright-faithhopelove.blogs... Dx 2/12/2009, IBC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: life insurance patti4511 DARLENEDENISE

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 12:58AM cwrightrn wrote: I found the post from FLALADY and here is what she said: " I did Ixempra for six months with Xeloda (this combo does show to work better)  this clear up my tumor for three months but when this drug stop working the cancer/tumors came back extremely aggressive.  I have four other friend who were TN and had this same thing happened. Also many had eye sight problems that have not went away after treatment.  I would ask about the research for TN that has came out in the last three years by patients not trials.  Also make sure they give it weekly low dose because it has been proven this is just as effective as once every three weeks.  The fatigue with this chemo can be very hard on you. " Hope that helps......
Posts.Title: Anyone on Ixempra - esp. TN? Duffymom kenzie57

Posts.Content: cwrightrn wrote: HI Ladies---so my 9 week old cough that won't go away remains annoying.  2 weeks ago I had a CT scan that showed no pneumonia but a bit of scarring in the left upper lobe from rads--but not enough to cause me to be so symptomatic.  This week my PET scan showed "ground glass opacity" in the left lower lobe--a change from 2 weeks ago.  The radiologist said it was from inflammation.  The pulmonologist/oncologist aren't so convinced.  They said it can be from inflammation, infection or spread.  I had a bronch this week but they couldn't do a biopsy because of my recent avastin use. But they did brushings that were all negative for infection.  So infection is ruled out.  Because I have had recent skin mets recurrence, the oncologist is suspicious it is lymphangitic spread to the lungs. There were NO nodules or anything glaring at the pulmonologist during the bronch which is good news (one site I googled about this type of spread said that nodules are usually present).  I am convinced that the avastin caused the cough (it got worse with each avastin dose) and that time will clear it up....at least I'm praying for that.  Just wondering if anyone else has this or has heard of it.  The oncologist isn't in a rush to do a biopsy cause I am going back on chemo--and I don't want to do another bronch any time soon.  I am now taking hydrocodone either as pill or in cough syrup to help me sleep at night-- nothing else works--not inhalers, steroids (I'm on 40mg of prednisone), antihistamines, etc... Believe me, I've tried everything. Anyone with any experience out there?  After being on avastin/abraxane I will switch either to a Parp/gemzar/carboplat (if I can get it for compassionate use) or Ixempra/xeloda--I'm worried about the Ixempra/xeloda combo as I've heard it works well but when it comes back it is super charged.  Thanks for your thoughts. I know I can always depend on you ladies!!  Visit our blog: www.wright-faithhopelove.blogs... Dx 2/12/2009, IBC, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 02:10AM cwrightrn wrote: Nanalinda---it might be best to call your insurance company to find out about the accelerated benefits option because not every policy has it (for some it depends on the money amount of the policy) and not every company does it from what I've discovered.  As to the Dr signing a life expectancy form--that varies from state to state according to Metlife--I live in washington state and my Dr needs to sign off on 24 month expectancy but most states its 12 months. Believe me when I say I'm not an expert....just letting you know what I found out from Met Life  Hope that helps Carole

Posts.Content: May 12, 2010 01:18AM cwrightrn wrote: Not to bash Dr Oz or anything but you all know he is a cardiothoracic surgeon, right?  Anything on his programs out of that realm I would be really leery to watch.  Unfortunately most of the public think a Dr is a Dr but it isn't true....they have fields of expertise.  I worked in a Cardiac intensive care unit and believe me, if you called the cardiothoracic surgeon for anything beside the heart/ lung/ surgery he just performed he would send you to a general practice Dr.....  Anyway, those are just my thoughts.
Posts.Title: Today's DR Oz show neogirl konakat

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2010 04:10PM cwrightrn wrote: Be very careful with policies advertised on TV....many do not give you the full amount until you have paid into them for several years. So make sure you ask "is the full amount effective day one?" They will pay out what you have paid into it plus interest, but not the full amount.   Good luck on your search but there isn't anything I have found....
Posts.Title: life insurance patti4511 DARLENEDENISE

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2010 12:24PM cwrightrn wrote: I am on Ixempra (which is an IV drug given once every 3 weeks) and Xeloda.  I started with 1500 of xeloda twice a day, 7 days on, 7 days off.  Now I take 2000mg of Xeloda on the same schedule.  I had a CT 3 months into treatment and all cancer was stable or slightly better.  so I will stay on the regimen for another 3 months.  I use bag balm (you have to ask for it at the Walmart pharmacy counter--it is not by prescription but not kept on the shelves) at night--I smother my hands and wear gloves all night and I smother my feet and wear socks all night.  I wear soft slippers at home or supportive cushiony flip flops when going out and have had no problems with the hand/foot syndrome.  I have heard henna also recommended as a moisturizer but haven't used it yet.  Hang in there!  Blessings and hugs
Posts.Title: New to Discussions dejam dejam

Posts.Content: May 20, 2010 01:13PM cwrightrn wrote: Tyra, I feel your pain.  My dr's clinical opinion is that I have lymphangitic lung spread and I have had a severe cough for 4 months and NOTHING works.  Nmiller, as above, did say that roxanol (liquid morphine) helped her but it did not help me....it gave only 2 hours of relief so I tried that twice and didn't like the idea of taking that much morphine all through the night.  I am on steroids, have tried inhalers, rx cough syrup, humidifier, had a bronchoscopy, elevated head, drank everything under the sun ALL TO NO AVAIL.  There is a rx cough syrup tussionex (that has hydrocodone 10mg) in it that the pulmonologist suggested and it sas $60 for the bottle and I could only take a little bit every 8 hours.  My oncologist finally said it was the codeine that was curbing the cough and said to take rx pain medicine, specifically hydrocodone (lortab) 10 with 325mg of tylenol.  The standard dose is hydrocodone 10mg with 500 mg of tylenol and you can only take 8 pills a day safely so she cut the tylenol to 325mg and you can take more.  I now take a half a tab at noon, a half a tab at 4pm, 2 tabs at 8pm and 2 tabs at midnight and I am getting some rest---sometimes I get up at 3am or 5am and take 2 more tabs.  I'm not happy about taking this much pain medicine---I had a total hip replacement and didn't take this much pain medicine!!  My dr thinks that the new chemo I started last week will kick the cough but it might take a month.  Make sure mention what is going on to the dr...ask if they want you to have a bronchoscopy to see if there is anything causing the cough....ask about steroids and the hydrocodone.   Feel free to PM me anytime.  Hope this helps Blessings and hugs from a fellow sufferer Carole
Posts.Title: my cough hurts so bad tyra MJLToday

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 12:52AM cwrightrn wrote: HI Kathy--hopefully FLALADY will come along and respond to you. I believe she told me that she did lxempra and had a difficult time with it.  Sorry to not have more info for you...hang in there!
Posts.Title: Anyone on Ixempra - esp. TN? Duffymom kenzie57

Posts.Content: May 20, 2010 05:03AM cwrightrn wrote: Thanks for your post Larissa--so sorry you have the cough too.  My oncologist said that her clinical judgment is that it is spread, not inflammation.  I started ixempra/xeloda last week and we are praying that it kicks the cough---but it might take up to a month. After trying inhalers, steroids, humidifier, 2 rx cough syrups and roxanol (morphine liquid)--which all just lasted me 2 hours, I am now taking lortab 10/325.  Lortab has hydrocodone which is in the rx cough syrups but you can take  the pain pills more often.  I try to manage with a half tablet a few times during the day and then at 8pm I take 2 tables and 2 more at midnight--I've been getting at least 5 consecutive hours sleep with this concoction---better than only 2 hours at a time!  Make sure that if you use the lortab that it has just 325mg of tylenol, not the standard 500mg or you are limited on the amount of pain pills you can take in a day because of the max dose of tylenol. Hope that helps.....feel free to PM me anytime.  nmiller--still hoping to hear from you via PM to see how the prednisone is working for you.   Believe me, 4 months of this is wearing me thin and I'm praying for an answer Hang in there Carole
Posts.Title: Lymphangitic lung spread cwrightrn joju

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2010 05:04PM cwrightrn wrote: I hope its not too late to ask a question.  Are the life insurance policies you ladies are talking about private policies or through your job?  I have been on a leave of absence for a year and they are holding my job til July but my Dr wants me to quit---I'm a nurse in a very busy intensive care unit.  anyway, my benefits have lapsed and the life insurance policy I carried can be rolled over through Met Life but it is dramatically lower.  As to the retirement account, I would be taxed 20-30% to get a disbursement (I am 40 years old) unless I roll it over.  We found out we can roll it over to an IRA and then withdraw and be taxed either 0 if declared disabled or 10% if I don't meet their requirements.  We consulted a tax advisor and she said that whether we are taxed 10% right away or not, she recommends keeping 10% to the side because we will owe that much to the government.  As to the house, we don't have that insurance that if something happens to me it would be paid off---ugh!  Anyway, just wondering what kind of life insurance policy you are drawing from.  Thanks for your thoughts

Posts.Content: May 10, 2010 03:36PM cwrightrn wrote: Linda--why so long on Navelbine before thinking of switching chemos? That seems like an awfully long time especially if you feel the tumor growing! My Dr keeps me on a cocktail for 3 months then does a scan.  We also "watch" the trend of tumor markers although we don't take much stock in them.  Can you talk to the Dr more about switching chemos--or why you need to be on it so long before a change?   Insurance companies SUCK.  Sorry, but I can't think of a better word.  Is there a process whereby your Dr can petition for a scan sooner?  Or, like mentioned above, a different scan or test? Blessings and hugs and prayers are being sent your way my dear TN friend.  Hang in there!  Carole
Posts.Title: Navelbine Is Not Working Nanalinda Marybe

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2010 09:18PM cwrightrn wrote: I agree with Lisa....in my case they mean nothing.  My first marker at diagnosis was slightly elevated when I had a ton of disease.....and it went higher after chemo (but the Dr thinks it was related to taking neulasta).   Hang in there Blessings and hugs Carole
Posts.Title: Tumor Markers goldengirl goldengirl

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2010 01:36AM cwrightrn wrote: I have been on abraxane and avastin for a month now and the abraxane is much milder than the taxol I had and the infusion time is MUCH shorter--thankfully!  I have no nausea and a little fatigue...I was told to expect hair loss but I don't have much anyway! As to your question about why abraxane wasn't first choice....it is my understanding that taxol or taxotere need to be attempted first.  Hope it works well for your Mom!
Posts.Title: Switching Mom to Abraxane sincitydealer traciedg

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2009 05:46PM cwrightrn wrote: PS...my best friend from work was an oncology asst manager for years and had never heard of inflammatory breast cancer--who would think something could pop up overnight but it did (and was bad!). So we don't know everything....she has been a godsend to me though with all my appts and helping me with info, being another set of ears when I couldn't hear at the beginning of diagnosis). AND, one of my good friends that I graduated nursing school with was diagnosed a few months after me--YIKES!!

Posts.Title: On a lighter note -this is all true pattih cwrightrn

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 07:49PM cwrightrn wrote: 2 things.....first off, will the bride consent to a scarf or something that can be tied around the chest with a nice broach or something?  I was in a wedding (pre-cancer) and the dresses were sleeveless and NONE of us were small ladies--I was mortified til the day of the wedding when the bride had sewn us all velvet scarves (throws--whatever they are called) and it covered us all nicely...not cause we didn't have boobs, but because we were all pretty heavy! Second, I might be of the minority here but I do have foobs and I like them.  They help me feel "normal" and look good in clothes.  I was a DDD but my foobs are C cup because that is what the plastic surgeon said he could give me if I had plastic surgery (which I can't).  Anyway, insurance covered the foobs and 2 bras every 6 months--do you have a policy that might cover them?  I don't wear the foobs around the house unless we have people over...but I wear them to church and to do clothes shopping, etc....  Since I now have a nice spare tire around my middle I look quite out of proportion without my foobs.   Anyway, just a few notes from the peanut gallery
Posts.Title: Bride's maid blues KSkier redwoman

Posts.Content: May 10, 2010 03:14PM cwrightrn wrote: I'm just starting xeloda today and I was reading about how important it is to keep sunscreen on.  It also said that you can develop a dermatitis. Make sure you let the Dr know about what is going on... perhaps some benadryl would help since she is so swollen.   Please call and let the Dr know what is going on and see what the Dr would recommend Hang in there blessings and hugs Carole
Posts.Title: xeloda photosensitivity marieibrahim cwrightrn

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2010 02:00AM cwrightrn wrote: mbmoss--I too am TN and have a recent stage IV diagnosis. I read your past posts and noted that you did ACT at diagnosis and now cytoxin and taxol, right?  Why is xeloda next instead of avastin/abraxane or other IV chemo's...gemzar/carboplat, ixempra, etc...?  Just curious....  I've read a lot about xeloda and it working for many people.  I will have a scan in a few weeks to see if the avastin/abraxane is working for me....and being TN chemo will be lifelong so we will do some variation of it if its working or move to the next cocktail. Hang in there.... Blessings and hugs Carole
Posts.Title: Xeloda mbmoss mbmoss

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 01:54AM cwrightrn wrote: Step 1--admit you need help...YOU'VE DONE THAT!  Now call the Dr and get some meds to relieve your symptoms.  And remember, WE ARE ALL HERE FOR YOU! Blessings and hugs
Posts.Title: Sadness jleigh jleigh

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2010 12:26AM cwrightrn wrote: So glad to see this thread!  I have been on a leave of absence since February of last year and my job was being held til July of this year BUT I resigned this last week.  Since advancing to stage IV in January, I knew this day was coming but knowing I needed to give up my job was the hardest part of stage IV.  As a nurse, my job was more than a job but a ministry.  I have worked for 24 years and to give that up was difficult.  Thankfully I have SSDI and LTD. Thanks again for this post and for helping me to see the giving up of the job in a different light.
Posts.Title: Well, I finally made my announcement at work... Fitztwins ShirleyHughes

Posts.Content: May 14, 2010 12:10AM cwrightrn wrote: Just a note from the peanut gallery re: single agents to keep from running out of chemos.  Some chemos are MEANT to be given with others because of the way they work on the cells/mechanism of action/etc.  Not sure where the "single agent" thought comes from....it might make you feel better to think there are several drugs if used one at a time BUT they might not be effective alone.  Just a note from the peanut gallery
Posts.Title: Navelbine Is Not Working Nanalinda Marybe

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2009 05:30PM cwrightrn wrote: Hello everyone...I'm new to the website and so glad I found this leg of the forum!!  I have been an RN for 18 years....med surg for a few years, oncology for 4 years then telemetry, dabbled in IV therapy and recovery room and have been in the Cardiac Intensive Care unit for the last 5 working full time nocs, 12 hour shifts. I had been doing charge nursing and working on the rapid response team and had 2 sentinel events in December (prior to diagnosis) caused by the same CRNA that I had to go to tons of meetings for....nothing like a little stress, right?  And YES, night shift was my risk factor for breast cancer- ugh!!  (I had an aunt who had bc but a different type and my BRCA was negative). My manager has been very supportive and I took short term disability at diagnosis...being superwoman I thought I could work but when everyone was crying, including some of the Dr's I knew I couldn't do it.  In fact, now that I'm done with mastectomy and facing more chemo with rads the Dr said I could go back BUT I work in a cesspool of germs and have opted to shift to long term disability (I don't need ssdi yet).  My hospital will hold a job in house til July of next year so I have time....and my manager has assured me a job on my floor (thankfully).  I haven't read all the pages of this forum but was wondering if any of you went back to full time nocs?  I'm hoping to go back after the first of the year.  My unit will allow me to work 4 hour shifts to start and work my way back....just not sure what to do.  I have inflammatory breast cancer and the risk of recurrence in the first few years is very high and working full time would help my family in case I need to go on SSDI.  I have a friend on my unit that battled bc and is 5 years out and she is glad she came back to our floor, despite the stress because of the great patient care.  She thought I would be frustrated if I went to a less stressful but higher acuity area say like tele.  So that's my scoop....thanks for listening and for your thoughts... Carole
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: May 19, 2010 11:55PM cwrightrn wrote: I'm another TN'er--visit my profile page for my chemo regimen.  Went stage IV in January and tried Abraxane/avastin but it didn't work so I started Ixempra and xeloda last week and will be on it for 3 months.  PARPS are our future and my oncologist said they will be out of trial for compassionate use in July which gives us all great hope.   Hang in there...you are not alone Blessings and hugs Carole
Posts.Title: Triple negative with mets JerseyMom cwrightrn

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2009 11:23PM cwrightrn wrote: Lorijo--I was shocked to read you would lose your job.  Don't you have medical/personal leaves of absences?  I can be off for up to a year without losing my job--but I work in a huge facility.  I too am a CCU RN.  I have a friend at work who took a year off for breast cancer treatment and has successfully returned to work but has reminded me NOT to work night shift and watch the stress level...especially in CCU.  My only risk factors for breast cancer were 18 years of night shift and working in a stressful environment! Hang in there!
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10
